prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Redshift group A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup ok for continuum, and for possible bonus lines for z=1.3142-1.3228 and z=1.3965-1.4059

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the scientific justification, we can use extrapolation from the measured average Herschel flux to expect on average an integrated 850um continuum of 1.2mJy for a source. An RMS of 0.05mJy per 0.25" beam then allows us to map sources similar to or brighter than this average integrated continuum. We can also still detect total emission from individual sources fainter than this average, or put very strong limits on nondetections. We hence do not make an attempt to anticipate the flux of a given source, and use this RMS 0.05mJy and a nominal 'peak flux density per beam' of 0.5mJy throughout. While sources may vary around that peak flux density depending on total flux and structure, the peak will always be faint <few mJy, which does not raise dynamic range questions.
This is a continuum driven project, but because of the potential to detect CO(7-6) (and for high SFR CI(2-1)) we have used the 'spectral line' type to emulate the 'single continuum' type with the sole modification of removing the small gap between basebands (as recommended in helpdesk ticket #4538). This allows to reduce overheads by using the same setup for a group of sources with similar redshift, and still ensure that any expected line is at least 0.65GHz away from the edges of one of these combined basebands. We have done the necessary observed-rest calculations externally and express the observations in observed frequencies and a virtual z=0. To reflect the continuum driven nature of the project, we refer the RMS to a 'line' over the full aggregate bandwidth of the four basebands, which gives results as in 'single continuum'.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous L(2-10keV)>1E44 AGN at z>~1 are close to the redshift and AGN luminosity dominating accretion, and at the decisive point when cosmic accretion and star formation begins to decrease dramatically. Unlike lower luminosity AGN at similar redshift which are typically hosted by star forming main-sequence disks, little is known about the properties of their hosts and the mechanisms driving their evolution. We propose spatially resolved continuum observations of an unbiased sample of 18 such AGN in COSMOS, in order to quantify their star forming activity and shed light on the disk or merger nature of the hosts. Our goals are to (1) individually identify heavily star forming and passive hosts, (2) determine whether the spatial extent of star formation suggests large disks or compact mergers and (3) put the currently strongest observational constraints on the long wavelength emission heated by the AGN proper, essential for the interpretation of spatially unresolved Herschel and ALMA studies of high-z AGN hosts. Free bonus science will characterize the strength of CO(7-6) emission in a clean AGN sample, and cold ISM kinematics via CI(2-1) in few highest SFR sources.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: There is an executed cycle 0 spatially unresolved continuum proposal in COSMOS (2011.0.0097.S Scoville) which was however -not- targeting X-ray sources
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
